protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
description:
This is a protocol from: 

Stedman, K. M., K. Porter, and M. L. Dyall-Smith. 2010. Chapter 6: The isolation of viruses infecting Archaea. Manual of Aquatic Viral Ecology. Waco, TX:American Society of Limnology and Oceanography. doi:10.4319/mave.2010.978-0-9845591-0-7

Please see the published manuscript for additional information.

collections.protocol_name: The Isolation of Viruses Infecting Archaea
collections.protocol_name_html: The Isolation of Viruses Infecting Archaea

authors: Kenneth M. Stedman, Kate Porter, and Mike L. Dyall-Smith
guidelines:
Authors: Kenneth M. Stedman1, Kate Porter2, and Mike L. Dyall-Smith3
1Department of Biology, Center for Life in Extreme Environments, Portland State University, P.O. Box 751, Portland, OR 97207, USA
2Biota Holdings Limited, 10/585 Blackburn Road, Notting Hill Victoria 3168, Australia
3Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry, Department of Membrane Biochemistry, Am Klopferspitz 18, 82152 Martinsried, Germany
Modified growth medium (MGM) contains 5 g peptone and 1 g yeast extract per liter of salt water. The salt concentration is varied according to the host strain, and is detailed in the Halohandbook.

components.data: Salt lake samples are collected from hypersaline waters, which typically range from 15% w/v total salt, up to saturation (ca 35%).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Salt lake samples are collected from hypersaline waters, which typically range from 15% w/v total salt, up to saturation (ca 35%).

components.data: Samples are collected in sterile 5–10 mL vessels and may be stored for several weeks at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Samples are collected in sterile 5–10 mL vessels and may be stored for several weeks at room temperature.

components.data: In the laboratory, cells and cellular debris are removed by centrifugation (5,000g, 10 min, room temperature).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In the laboratory, cells and cellular debris are removed by centrifugation (5,000g, 10 min, room temperature).

components.data: The supernatant is then screened directly for viruses by plaque assay.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The supernatant is then screened directly for viruses by plaque assay.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.annotation: The use of chloroform is avoided, because it is known to have a detrimental affect on both phage-like and lipid-containing haloviruses.
source_data.thread_text: The use of chloroform is avoided, because it is known to have a detrimental affect on both phage-like and lipid-containing haloviruses.
source_data.body: The use of chloroform is avoided, because it is known to have a detrimental affect on both phage-like and lipid-containing haloviruses.

components.data: The choice of host strains depends on the experimental objectives, and includes well-characterized members of the Halobacteriaceae, such as Hbt. salinarum (host for ΦH and several others) or Har. hispanica (host for SH1, His1, His2, and others), or natural isolates from the same source, such as Hrr. coriense (host for HF2).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The choice of host strains depends on the experimental objectives, and includes well-characterized members of the Halobacteriaceae, such as Hbt. salinarum (host for ΦH and several others) or Har. hispanica (host for SH1, His1, His2, and others), or natural isolates from the same source, such as Hrr. coriense (host for HF2).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.annotation: To maximize isolation success, several hosts should be used for the same sample. The advantage of the use of characterized hosts is that methods for genetic manipulation are often established and their genome sequences have been determined.
source_data.thread_text: To maximize isolation success, several hosts should be used for the same sample. The advantage of the use of characterized hosts is that methods for genetic manipulation are often established and their genome sequences have been determined.
source_data.body: To maximize isolation success, several hosts should be used for the same sample. The advantage of the use of characterized hosts is that methods for genetic manipulation are often established and their genome sequences have been determined.

components.data: Base and overlay plates (90 mm) are made with MGM (see guidelines), solidified using 15% w/v agar.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Base and overlay plates (90 mm) are made with MGM (see guidelines), solidified using 15% w/v agar.

components.data: A range of salt water concentrations should be examined, because salt concentration seems to greatly affect the size and clarity of plaques.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: A range of salt water concentrations should be examined, because salt concentration seems to greatly affect the size and clarity of plaques.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.annotation: Using salt water concentrations that are 2% to 5% lower than the optimum for host growth commonly gives better plaques.
source_data.thread_text: Using salt water concentrations that are 2% to 5% lower than the optimum for host growth commonly gives better plaques.
source_data.body: Using salt water concentrations that are 2% to 5% lower than the optimum for host growth commonly gives better plaques.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 7 of Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.annotation: Incubation temperature is also important, because some haloviruses plaque poorly or not at all at 37–42°C, whereas they form clear plaques at 30°C.
source_data.thread_text: Incubation temperature is also important, because some haloviruses plaque poorly or not at all at 37–42°C, whereas they form clear plaques at 30°C.
source_data.body: Incubation temperature is also important, because some haloviruses plaque poorly or not at all at 37–42°C, whereas they form clear plaques at 30°C.

components.data: Plates can be stored indefinitely at 4°C (wrapped in plastic to prevent dessication), but should be warmed to room temperature or warmer for use.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Plates can be stored indefinitely at 4°C (wrapped in plastic to prevent dessication), but should be warmed to room temperature or warmer for use.

components.data: For virus isolation, 100–500 µl of the cleared water sample is mixed with 150 µl of exponentially growing host cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For virus isolation, 100–500 µl of the cleared water sample is mixed with 150 µl of exponentially growing host cells.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 9 of Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of Haloviruses from Natural Waters
source_data.annotation: These may be characterized strains of haloarchaea, or natural isolates, for example, isolates from the natural water sample.
source_data.thread_text: These may be characterized strains of haloarchaea, or natural isolates, for example, isolates from the natural water sample.
source_data.body: These may be characterized strains of haloarchaea, or natural isolates, for example, isolates from the natural water sample.

components.data: Then, 3–4 mL of molten (50°C) top-layer MGM (with 0.7% w/v agar) is added, and the solution mixed gently and poured evenly over the plate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Then, 3–4 mL of molten (50°C) top-layer MGM (with 0.7% w/v agar) is added, and the solution mixed gently and poured evenly over the plate.

components.data: After setting on a level surface for 5–10 min, plates are incubated aerobically, inverted in airtight containers at 30°C and 37°C for 1–4 d, and checked every day for plaques.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After setting on a level surface for 5–10 min, plates are incubated aerobically, inverted in airtight containers at 30°C and 37°C for 1–4 d, and checked every day for plaques.

components.data: Any visible plaques are picked using sterile glass Pasteur pipettes, or sterile plastic micropipette tips.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Any visible plaques are picked using sterile glass Pasteur pipettes, or sterile plastic micropipette tips.

components.data:
These agar plugs are then transferred to tubes containing 500 µl of halovirus diluent:
2.47 M NaCl
90 mM MgCl2
90 mM MgSO4
60 mM KCl
3 mM CaCl2
10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
These agar plugs are then transferred to tubes containing 500 µl of halovirus diluent:
2.47 M NaCl
90 mM MgCl2
90 mM MgSO4
60 mM KCl
3 mM CaCl2
10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5

components.data: They are then vortexed to homogenize the sample.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: They are then vortexed to homogenize the sample.

components.data: These suspensions are then replaqued on overlay plates to purify the isolates and to eliminate “false plaques” caused by artifacts in the agar overlay or contaminants in the water sample.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: These suspensions are then replaqued on overlay plates to purify the isolates and to eliminate “false plaques” caused by artifacts in the agar overlay or contaminants in the water sample.
